Robert Lucente wrote:

> "But still, I agree with the concept that buying hardware should at least be
> *considered* an option ..."
> 
> That was the point. Look at ALL the technical optinons and then judge them
> against risk/cost/ and so on. I just have seen too many times people propose
> the "technical elegant solution" which was not "optimal from a business
> perspective".

Indeed! This is a key point that goes well beyond programming. It 
assumes, for example, that we programmers are fiscally literate, such as 
able to read a financial statement.

By show of hands, how many of us can do that?

I do, frequently, because I run businesses that have nothing to do with 
shipping software. Making a business-oriented judgment, such as "just 
add RAM" is easy for me. I can see the whole picture, because I do so 
daily. Even the very best programmers count among them some people who 
don't know what "COGS" means.

So perhaps I was rash in saying that any decent consultant wouldn't tell 
his client, "just add RAM." I shouldn't assume that a software 
consultant speaks business, although I would avoid hiring one that didn't.

Take care.
